lesson_html:
Python lists have powerful built-in methods similar to C# 'List' methods. Key methods include:

Modification Methods

  • append(): Adds an element to the end (like C# Add())
  • insert(index, element): Inserts element at specific position (similar to C# Insert())
  • remove(element): Removes first occurrence of element (like C# Remove())
  • pop(): Removes and returns last element (similar to C# RemoveAt())

Searching Methods

  • index(element): Returns index of first occurrence (like C# IndexOf())
  • count(element): Counts occurrences of an element (similar to LINQ Count())

Sorting and Transformation

  • sort(): In-place sorting (like C# Sort())
  • reverse(): Reverses list in-place (similar to C# Reverse())

Example usage:

numbers = [3, 1, 4, 1, 5]
numbers.append(9)  # [3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9]
numbers.sort()    # [1, 1, 3, 4, 5, 9]
print(numbers.count(1))  # 2
